input:

The referee and one of his assistants both point at the corner flag.

45:11 Caption: The end of the first half.
45:59 Caption: It wasn't the most inspiring 45 minutes that you'll see this week. Let's hope that the second period will be more exciting. There wasn't any evident superiority by either side during the first half. Both sides are using combination football to try and gain the upper hand.

The ball goes out of play and Liverpool will have a goal kick.

46:41 Caption: Raheem Sterling slides a brilliant pass into Martin Skrtel (Liverpool), but his shot from inside the box goes a whisker wide of the left post. The ball goes out of play and Basel will have a goal kick.
47:42 Caption: Chance! Jordan Henderson (Liverpool) gets to the rebound on the edge of the box and smashes the ball towards the left side of the goal, but Tomas Vaclik is alert and makes a save to deny him.

49:06 Caption: The referee blows for the end of today's match.
49:59 Caption: The fans can't complain about what they saw on the pitch as both sides displayed a highly captivating football match. The performance of both teams was pretty much even. The home team played possession football and the away players really focused on a well-organized defence.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
On a crisp evening at Anfield, Liverpool faced off against Basel in what promised to be an intriguing contest. The first half began with Liverpool kicking off, immediately setting the tone for an intense battle. Just 31 seconds into the game, the ball went out of play, a glimpse into the tightly contested nature that would define much of the match.

Liverpool's intent to assert dominance early was clear with a series of offensive maneuvers. Raheem Sterling, proving to be a thorn in Basel's side from the outset, found space to shoot twice within the first three minutes, but his efforts were either saved or sailed off target. Basel's defense was steadily tested, but they managed to clear their lines efficiently.

The game saw multiple interruptions as both teams struggled to maintain possession without errors. Clearances and throw-ins punctuated the early exchanges, reflecting the high tempo yet somewhat scrappy nature of play. Liverpool found themselves on the call for a couple of early fouls committed by the Basel players, earning them indirect free-kicks that, unfortunately, came to nothing.

A notable early incident was when Luca Zuffi's pass towards Shkelzen Gashi culminated in a near-miss, Basel's offensive threat clear from the get-go. Liverpool's response was swift, with Sterling again making inroads but failing to penetrate the Basel defense. The Swiss side was not passive though; they countered repeatedly, represented well by shots from Gashi and Frei that kept the Reds on their toes.

Liverpool's pressing strategy saw Steven Gerrard playing deep crosses into the box, but Basel's defensive resilience held firm. In the 24th minute, Basel's Fabian Frei broke the deadlock. Seizing upon a loose ball on the edge of the box, Frei launched a first-time shot, finding the bottom right corner of the net – a sublime finish that stunned the home crowd and left Simon Mignolet with no chance. This goal symbolized Basel’s efficient use of counter-attacks and precise finishing.

Raheem Sterling immediately tried to answer back for Liverpool, but his formidable shot was superbly saved by Tomas Vaclik, denying Liverpool an equalizer and showcasing exactly why this Basel team should not be underestimated. The frustration of the Liverpool players began to show, with a string of fouls resulting in Jordan Henderson and Raheem Sterling being penalized for their overly aggressive attempts to win back possession.

The game saw many stoppages for fouls and offsides, breaking the rhythm and making it hard for either side to establish prolonged dominance. The first half ended with Basel holding on to their one-goal advantage, despite multiple threats from a Liverpool team determined not to succumb to early setbacks.

Following halftime, Liverpool made two significant substitutions, with Lazar Markovic and Alberto Moreno coming on for Rickie Lambert and Jose Enrique respectively. These substitutions indicated Brendan Rodgers' intent to shake things up and inject fresh energy into the squad. Basel restarted the game and Liverpool quickly took charge, looking to level the score. Steven Gerrard epitomized this, soon after resumption, with a long-range shot that blazed wide.

In the 47th minute, Liverpool's Lucas Leiva was booked for a late challenge, symptomatic of Liverpool’s committed but often desperate attempts to disrupt Basel’s play. Basel, in turn, launched into attack mode with their own free-kick attempts. Fabian Schar's powerful shot from distance, however, did not trouble Mignolet much, flying comfortably wide.

The tension bubbled as Liverpool's attacking play became increasingly frenetic. Sterling and Gerrard continued to find pockets of space but were often thwarted by Basel's defensive organization. In the 54th minute, Lazar Markovic was shown a red card, reducing Liverpool to ten men. It was a moment that significantly altered the dynamic of the game, presenting Basel with an opportunity to capitalize on their numerical advantage.

Despite being a man down, Liverpool continued pushing hard. Their perseverance paid off in the 67th minute. Steven Gerrard, ever the clutch performer, stepped up to take a free-kick from just outside the box. His effort was immaculate, curling the ball into the net off the inside of the left post, leaving the keeper with no chance – a breathtaking goal that drew Liverpool level and breathed fresh life into the match.

The latter stages of the game saw a flurry of activity, with both teams jostling for control. Basel made substitutions to bring fresh legs onto the pitch, focusing on maintaining their defensive shape while trying to exploit gaps left by an advancing Liverpool side. Notable was the substitution of Marco Streller for Breel Embolo, an attempt by Basel to inject fresh attacking vigor.

As the match drew towards its climax, chances came thick and fast. Both goalkeepers were called into action frequently, with Mignolet making several key saves to keep Liverpool's hopes alive. Vaclik, not to be outdone, mirrored this with critical interventions as Liverpool threw everything at Basel in the dying moments.

The game wasn’t devoid of defensive heroics either. Martin Skrtel and Dejan Lovren were tenacious at the back for Liverpool, their physical presence crucial in dealing with Basel's sporadic forays forward. Basel’s defensive steel was epitomized by Tomas Vaclik’s composure and reflexes, particularly in the face of relentless pressure from Liverpool’s dynamic forwards like Sterling and Gerrard.

As the clock ticked into its final minutes, the tension was palpable. Liverpool’s relentless pressure saw Steven Gerrard attempting multiple shots from distance, each either blocked by defenders or saved by the keeper. On the other hand, Basel's counter-attacks, although incisive, failed to yield the decisive goal as they were snuffed out by Liverpool’s last-ditch defending.

The final whistle blew with the score locked at 1-1. It was a match that demonstrated the resilience of both teams, highlighting the tactical nous and defensive discipline of Basel against Liverpool's relentless attacking vigor and never-say-die attitude. The fans at Anfield witnessed a contest full of passion, close calls, and moments of brilliance, particularly Gerrard's stunning free-kick which will be remembered for years. The match, with its strategic depth, individual performances, and dramatic twists, encapsulated the very essence of football excitement.
